notes.title: Definition and Discovery
points: A number 's' is called irrational if it cannot be written in the form $p/q$, where $p$ and $q$ are integers and $q \neq 0$.
Pythagoreans were the first to discover numbers that were not rational, starting with $\sqrt{2}$.
Every real number is represented by a unique point on the number line.

notes.title: Locating on Number Line
points: Irrational numbers like $\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3}$ can be located using the Pythagoras Theorem.
For $\sqrt{n}$, we first locate $\sqrt{n-1}$ on the number line.

formulas.title: Pythagoras Application
formulas.explanation: Used to find the length of the hypotenuse which represents the irrational value on the number line.

realworld.title: Paper Sizes
realworld.description: Standard A4 paper uses the ratio $1 : \sqrt{2}$. This ensures that when you fold the paper in half, the new shape has the same proportions as the original.

topics.name: Real Numbers and their Decimal Expansions

notes.title: Rational Number Expansions
points: The decimal expansion of a rational number is either terminating or non-terminating recurring.
Example: $1/2 = 0.5$ (Terminating), $1/3 = 0.333...$ (Recurring).

notes.title: Irrational Number Expansions
points: The decimal expansion of an irrational number is non-terminating non-recurring.
Example: $\pi = 3.14159265...$ (never repeats or ends).

formulas.title: Conversion to p/q form
formulas.explanation: Algebraic method to convert repeating decimals back into rational fractions.

realworld.title: Digital Storage
realworld.description: Computers cannot store non-terminating decimals infinitely. They use 'floating point' representation to round real numbers, which is crucial for graphics and simulations.

notes.title: Algebraic Properties
points: The sum or difference of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational.
The product or quotient of a non-zero rational number with an irrational number is irrational.
If we add, subtract, multiply or divide two irrationals, the result may be rational or irrational.

notes.title: Rationalising the Denominator
points: When the denominator of an expression contains a term with a square root, rationalising makes it easier to calculate.
To rationalise $1/(\sqrt{a}+b)$, multiply numerator and denominator by $(\sqrt{a}-b)$.

formulas.title: Square Root Identities
formulas.explanation: Allows breaking down complex radicals into simpler factors.

formulas.title: Conjugate Multiplication
formulas.explanation: The core formula used to rationalise denominators.

realworld.title: Civil Engineering
realworld.description: Engineers use operations on radicals to calculate the exact tension in bridge cables where distances involve diagonal measurements.

topics.name: Laws of Exponents for Real Numbers

notes.title: Extended Laws
points: Laws of exponents apply to both rational and irrational bases.
For a positive real number $a$ and rational exponents $p$ and $q$, laws like product and power of a power apply.
Negative exponents indicate the reciprocal of the base.

formulas.title: Product and Quotient Laws
formulas.formula: a^p \cdot a^q = a^{p+q}, \quad a^p / a^q = a^{p-q}
formulas.explanation: Rules for simplifying expressions with the same base.

formulas.title: Power of a Power
formulas.explanation: Multiplying exponents when a power is raised to another power.

realworld.title: Data Science
realworld.description: Laws of exponents are used to model the growth of viral social media posts or the spread of a virus in a population.

notes.title: Introduction to Polynomials
points: A polynomial is an algebraic expression consisting of variables, coefficients, and non-negative integer exponents.
General form: p(x) = aₙxⁿ + aₙ₋₁xⁿ⁻¹ + ... + a₁x + a₀, where aₙ, aₙ₋₁, ..., a₀ are constants and n is a non-negative integer.
The highest power of x in p(x) is called the degree of the polynomial.

notes.title: Types of Polynomials
points: Based on terms: Monomial (1 term), Binomial (2 terms), Trinomial (3 terms).
Based on degree: Linear (degree 1), Quadratic (degree 2), Cubic (degree 3), etc.
A polynomial of degree 0 is called a constant polynomial.

formulas.title: Polynomial Degree
formulas.explanation: The highest power of the variable in the polynomial determines its degree.

realworld.title: Motion Physics
realworld.description: The position of an object moving with constant acceleration is modeled by a quadratic polynomial in time (s = ut + ½at²).

notes.title: Understanding Zeroes
points: A real number k is called a zero of polynomial p(x) if p(k) = 0.
Geometrically, zeroes represent the x-coordinates of points where the graph of p(x) intersects the x-axis.
A polynomial of degree n can have at most n zeroes.

notes.title: Finding Zeroes
points: For linear polynomial ax + b, zero is x = -b/a.
For quadratic polynomials, zeroes can be found using factorization or the quadratic formula.
The number of times a particular zero occurs is called its multiplicity.

formulas.title: Quadratic Formula
formulas.explanation: Used to find zeroes of quadratic polynomial ax² + bx + c.

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: The zeroes of the quadratic equation representing a projectile's height vs. time graph give the time of flight, while the vertex gives the maximum height.

notes.title: Theorem Statement
points: If a polynomial p(x) is divided by (x - a), the remainder is p(a).
This provides a quick way to evaluate polynomials at specific points.
If p(a) = 0, then (x - a) is a factor of p(x).

formulas.title: Remainder Formula
formulas.formula: \text{If } p(x) = (x - a)q(x) + r, \text{ then } r = p(a)
formulas.explanation: When p(x) is divided by (x - a), the remainder r equals p(a).

realworld.title: Error Detection
realworld.description: The Remainder Theorem is used in creating check digits for error detection in barcodes and credit card numbers, similar to the Luhn algorithm.

notes.title: Factor Theorem
points: (x - a) is a factor of polynomial p(x) if and only if p(a) = 0.
This helps in factorizing higher degree polynomials by finding their zeroes first.
For quadratic polynomials, we can use the 'splitting the middle term' method.

notes.title: Factorization Methods
points: Common Factor: ax + ay = a(x + y)
Difference of Squares: a² - b² = (a - b)(a + b)
Perfect Square: a² ± 2ab + b² = (a ± b)²
Sum/Difference of Cubes: a³ ± b³ = (a ± b)(a² ∓ ab + b²)

formulas.title: Quadratic Factorization
formulas.explanation: Method to factorize quadratic polynomials by finding two numbers that add to the coefficient of x and multiply to the constant term.

realworld.title: Engineering Design
realworld.description: Factorization helps engineers analyze system stability by finding the roots of characteristic equations in control systems and structural analysis.

notes.title: Standard Identities
points: (a + b)² = a² + 2ab + b²
(a - b)² = a² - 2ab + b²
a² - b² = (a - b)(a + b)
(x + a)(x + b) = x² + (a + b)x + ab
(a + b + c)² = a² + b² + c² + 2ab + 2bc + 2ca

notes.title: Cubic Identities
points: (a + b)³ = a³ + b³ + 3ab(a + b)
(a - b)³ = a³ - b³ - 3ab(a - b)
a³ + b³ = (a + b)(a² - ab + b²)
a³ - b³ = (a - b)(a² + ab + b²)

formulas.title: Square of Trinomial
formulas.explanation: Expands the square of the sum of three terms, useful in geometry and physics calculations.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Algebraic identities are used to calculate areas of complex shapes by breaking them down into simpler geometric forms, essential in architectural design and construction planning.

notes.title: Introduction to Cartesian Plane
points: The Cartesian plane is a two-dimensional plane formed by two perpendicular number lines intersecting at the origin (0,0).
The horizontal number line is called the x-axis, and the vertical number line is called the y-axis.
The point of intersection of the axes is called the origin, denoted by O(0,0).
The axes divide the plane into four quadrants: I, II, III, and IV, moving counterclockwise from the upper right.

notes.title: Coordinates of a Point
points: Any point in the plane can be represented as an ordered pair (x, y), where x is the abscissa (distance from y-axis) and y is the ordinate (distance from x-axis).
In the first quadrant: (+, +), second quadrant: (-, +), third quadrant: (-, -), and fourth quadrant: (+, -).
Points on the x-axis have coordinates (x, 0) and points on the y-axis have coordinates (0, y).

formulas.title: Distance from Axes
formulas.formula: \text{For point } P(x,y), \text{ distance from y-axis} = |x|, \text{ distance from x-axis} = |y|
formulas.explanation: The absolute value ensures distance is always non-negative.

formulas.title: Quadrant Identification
formulas.formula:
ext{Quadrant I: } x>0, y>0
	ext{Quadrant II: } x<0, y>0
	ext{Quadrant III: } x<0, y<0
	ext{Quadrant IV: } x>0, y<0
formulas.explanation: Rules to determine the quadrant based on the sign of coordinates.

realworld.title: Navigation Systems
realworld.description: The Cartesian coordinate system is fundamental in GPS technology, where locations on Earth are specified using latitude and longitude, similar to (x,y) coordinates.

realworld.title: Video Games
realworld.description: Game developers use the Cartesian plane to position characters, objects, and backgrounds in 2D games, with the origin typically at the top-left or center of the screen.

topics.name: Plotting a Point in the Plane

notes.title: Steps to Plot Points
points: Start at the origin (0,0).
Move |x| units along the x-axis (right if x is positive, left if negative).
From there, move |y| units parallel to the y-axis (up if y is positive, down if negative).
Mark the point and label it with its coordinates.

notes.title: Special Cases
points: Points on the x-axis: y-coordinate is 0 (e.g., (3,0), (-2,0)).
Points on the y-axis: x-coordinate is 0 (e.g., (0,4), (0,-1)).
Points on the line y = x have equal x and y coordinates (e.g., (2,2), (-3,-3)).
Points on the line y = -x have coordinates that are negatives of each other (e.g., (2,-2), (-5,5)).

formulas.title: Midpoint Formula
formulas.explanation: Finds the point exactly halfway between two given points.

formulas.title: Distance Between Two Points
formulas.explanation: Derived from the Pythagorean theorem, it calculates the straight-line distance between two points.

realworld.title: Urban Planning
realworld.description: City planners use coordinate geometry to design street grids, with avenues and streets forming the x and y axes, making it easy to locate any address as a coordinate pair.

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: In computer displays, each pixel is addressed using a coordinate system, with the origin typically at the top-left corner, allowing precise control over image rendering and display.

notes.title: Understanding Linear Equations
points: A linear equation in two variables can be written in the form: ax + by + c = 0, where a, b, and c are real numbers, and a and b are not both zero.
The solution of a linear equation is any ordered pair (x, y) that makes the equation true when the values are substituted in.
A linear equation in two variables has infinitely many solutions, which can be represented as (x, y) pairs.

notes.title: Finding Solutions
points: To find a solution, we can assign any real value to one variable and solve for the other.
For example, in the equation 2x + 3y = 12, if x = 0, then y = 4, giving the solution (0,4).
Different values of x will give different values of y, generating multiple solutions.

formulas.title: General Solution
formulas.formula: \text{For } ax + by + c = 0, \text{ express y in terms of x: } y = \frac{-ax - c}{b}
formulas.explanation: This gives the relationship between x and y for any solution of the equation.

formulas.title: Checking Solutions
formulas.formula: \text{For a solution } (x_0, y_0), \text{ verify: } ax_0 + by_0 + c = 0
formulas.explanation: A point is a solution if it satisfies the equation when substituted.

realworld.title: Budget Planning
realworld.description: If x represents the number of items purchased at price a and y represents the number of items purchased at price b, the total cost equation ax + by = Total Budget helps in financial planning.

topics.name: Graph of a Linear Equation in Two Variables

notes.title: Graphical Representation
points: The graph of a linear equation in two variables is always a straight line.
Every point (x, y) on the line represents a solution to the equation.
To graph: Find at least two solutions (points) and draw a line through them.

notes.title: Intercepts Method
points: X-intercept: Point where the graph crosses the x-axis (y=0).
Y-intercept: Point where the graph crosses the y-axis (x=0).
These two points are sufficient to draw the line.

formulas.title: Slope-Intercept Form
formulas.explanation: m is the slope (steepness) of the line, b is the y-intercept (where the line crosses the y-axis).

formulas.title: Two-Point Form
formulas.explanation: Equation of a line passing through points (x₁,y₁) and (x₂,y₂).

realworld.title: Distance-Time Graphs
realworld.description: In physics, the equation d = rt (distance = rate × time) is linear. The graph of distance vs. time is a straight line whose slope represents speed.

topics.name: Equations of Lines Parallel to x-axis and y-axis

notes.title: Lines Parallel to Axes
points: Equation of a line parallel to x-axis: y = k, where k is a constant.
Equation of a line parallel to y-axis: x = h, where h is a constant.
The x-axis itself has the equation y = 0, and the y-axis has the equation x = 0.

notes.title: Characteristics
points: A line parallel to the x-axis has zero slope (horizontal line).
A line parallel to the y-axis has an undefined slope (vertical line).
Horizontal lines represent constant functions (y is constant for all x).
Vertical lines are not functions (same x maps to multiple y values).

formulas.title: Horizontal Line
formulas.explanation: All points on this line have the same y-coordinate (k). The slope m = 0.

formulas.title: Vertical Line
formulas.explanation: All points on this line have the same x-coordinate (h). The slope is undefined.

realworld.title: Building Design
realworld.description: The floors of a building are horizontal lines (y = k), while the walls are vertical lines (x = h). This concept is fundamental in architectural drawings and construction.

notes.title: Basic Angle Types
points: Acute Angle: Measures between 0° and 90°
Right Angle: Exactly 90°
Obtuse Angle: Between 90° and 180°
Straight Angle: Exactly 180°
Reflex Angle: Between 180° and 360°
Complete Angle: Exactly 360°

notes.title: Angle Pairs Relationships
points: Complementary Angles: Two angles whose sum is 90°
Supplementary Angles: Two angles whose sum is 180°
Adjacent Angles: Angles with a common vertex and arm
Linear Pair: Adjacent angles that are supplementary
Vertically Opposite Angles: Equal angles formed by two intersecting lines

formulas.title: Angle Sum Property
formulas.formula: \text{If } \angle A \text{ and } \angle B \text{ are complementary, then } \angle A + \angle B = 90^\circ
formulas.explanation: The sum of measures of two complementary angles is always 90 degrees.

formulas.title: Linear Pair Axiom
formulas.formula: \text{If ray OC stands on line AB, then } \angle AOC + \angle COB = 180^\circ
formulas.explanation: The sum of adjacent angles formed by a ray standing on a line is 180 degrees.

realworld.title: Clock Angles
realworld.description: The hour and minute hands of a clock form different angle pairs throughout the day. At 3:00, they form a 90° angle, while at 6:00, they form a 180° angle (straight angle).

notes.title: Transversal Properties
points: A transversal is a line that intersects two or more lines at distinct points
When a transversal cuts two parallel lines, it forms eight angles
Pairs of corresponding angles are equal
Alternate interior angles are equal
Consecutive interior angles are supplementary

notes.title: Axioms and Theorems
points: Corresponding Angles Axiom: If a transversal intersects two parallel lines, then each pair of corresponding angles is equal
Converse of Corresponding Angles Axiom: If a transversal intersects two lines such that a pair of corresponding angles is equal, then the two lines are parallel
Lines parallel to the same line are parallel to each other

formulas.title: Angle Relationships
formulas.formula: \text{If } l \parallel m \text{ and t is a transversal:}\\\text{Corresponding } \angle s \text{ are equal}\\\text{Alternate interior } \angle s \text{ are equal}\\\text{Consecutive interior } \angle s \text{ are supplementary}
formulas.explanation: Key angle relationships when a transversal cuts parallel lines.

realworld.title: Railway Tracks
realworld.description: Railway tracks are classic examples of parallel lines. The sleepers act as transversals, maintaining the constant distance between the tracks. The angles formed between the tracks and sleepers follow the properties of angles made by a transversal with parallel lines.

topics.name: Angle Sum Property of a Triangle

notes.title: Triangle Angle Sum Theorem
points: The sum of the three interior angles of a triangle is always 180°
This is a fundamental property that holds true for all triangles, regardless of their type
The theorem can be proved by drawing a line parallel to one side of the triangle through the opposite vertex

notes.title: Exterior Angle Property
points: An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of its two interior opposite angles
The sum of all exterior angles of a triangle is 360°
Each exterior angle and its adjacent interior angle form a linear pair (sum to 180°)

formulas.title: Angle Sum Formula
formulas.explanation: The sum of all interior angles of any triangle equals 180 degrees.

formulas.title: Exterior Angle Theorem
formulas.formula: \text{In } \triangle ABC, \text{ if side BC is extended to D, then } \angle ACD = \angle A + \angle B
formulas.explanation: An exterior angle equals the sum of the two opposite interior angles.

realworld.title: Roof Truss Design
realworld.description: The angle sum property is crucial in designing roof trusses. Engineers use this property to calculate the angles at which beams must meet to maintain structural integrity, ensuring that the sum of angles at any joint in the truss follows the triangle angle sum property.

notes.title: Understanding Congruence
points: Two triangles are congruent if their corresponding sides and angles are equal
Congruent triangles are identical in shape and size
The symbol ≅ is used to denote congruence
Corresponding parts of congruent triangles are equal (CPCT)

notes.title: Basic Properties
points: Congruence is an equivalence relation (reflexive, symmetric, transitive)
If ΔABC ≅ ΔPQR, then AB = PQ, BC = QR, AC = PR and ∠A = ∠P, ∠B = ∠Q, ∠C = ∠R
The order of letters in the congruence statement indicates the correspondence

formulas.title: CPCT Theorem
formulas.formula: If ΔABC ≅ ΔPQR, then:\\AB = PQ, BC = QR, CA = RP\\∠A = ∠P, ∠B = ∠Q, ∠C = ∠R
formulas.explanation: Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles are equal

realworld.title: Engineering Structures
realworld.description: In bridge and roof truss design, congruent triangular units are used repeatedly to ensure even distribution of forces and structural stability.

notes.title: Congruence Rules
points: SAS (Side-Angle-Side): Two sides and included angle of one triangle equal to corresponding parts of another
ASA (Angle-Side-Angle): Two angles and included side of one triangle equal to corresponding parts of another
AAS (Angle-Angle-Side): Two angles and non-included side of one triangle equal to corresponding parts of another
SSS (Side-Side-Side): Three sides of one triangle equal to corresponding sides of another
RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side): Right-angled triangles with hypotenuse and one side equal

notes.title: Important Notes
points: AAA is not a congruence criterion (triangles can be similar but not necessarily congruent)
SSA is not a valid congruence criterion (except for right-angled triangles as RHS)
The included angle is the angle between the two sides being considered

formulas.title: RHS Congruence
formulas.formula: In right triangles, if hypotenuse and one side of one triangle are equal to the hypotenuse and corresponding side of another, the triangles are congruent.
formulas.explanation: Specific case for right-angled triangles

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Builders use triangle congruence principles to ensure identical support structures on both sides of a building, maintaining balance and symmetry in construction.

notes.title: Angle Sum Property
points: The sum of the three interior angles of a triangle is always 180°
This can be proved by drawing a line parallel to one side through the opposite vertex
The property holds true for all types of triangles (acute, right, obtuse)

notes.title: Exterior Angle Property
points: An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two interior opposite angles
The sum of all exterior angles of a triangle is 360°
Each exterior angle and its adjacent interior angle form a linear pair (sum to 180°)

formulas.title: Exterior Angle Formula
formulas.formula: In ΔABC, if side BC is extended to D, then ∠ACD = ∠A + ∠B
formulas.explanation: The exterior angle equals the sum of two opposite interior angles

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: Surveyors and GPS systems use triangle properties to calculate distances and positions. The sum of angles helps in determining the third angle when two are known.

notes.title: Triangle Inequality Theorem
points: The sum of any two sides of a triangle is greater than the third side
The difference of any two sides is less than the third side
In any triangle, the side opposite to the larger angle is longer
In any triangle, the angle opposite to the longer side is larger

notes.title: Important Results
points: The sum of any two sides > third side
The difference of any two sides < third side
The shortest distance between two points is a straight line
The sum of any two angles is less than 180°

formulas.title: Triangle Inequality
formulas.formula: For any triangle with sides a, b, c:\\|a - b| < c < a + b\\|b - c| < a < b + c\\|a - c| < b < a + c
formulas.explanation: The sum of any two sides must be greater than the third side

realworld.title: Geographic Mapping
realworld.description: The triangle inequality principle is used in mapping software to calculate the shortest path between points, ensuring that the direct route between two points is never longer than the sum of distances through any intermediate point.

topics.name: Angle Subtended by a Chord at a Point

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: A chord divides the circle into two regions called segments
The angle subtended by a chord at the center is twice the angle subtended at any point on the circumference in the same segment
Angles in the same segment of a circle are equal
The angle in a semicircle is a right angle (90°)
Equal chords of a circle subtend equal angles at the center

notes.title: Theorems and Proofs
points: Theorem: The perpendicular from the center of a circle to a chord bisects the chord
Theorem: The line drawn through the center of a circle to bisect a chord is perpendicular to the chord
Theorem: There is one and only one circle passing through three non-collinear points
Theorem: Equal chords of a circle are equidistant from the center
Theorem: Chords equidistant from the center of a circle are equal in length

formulas.title: Angle Subtended by Chord
formulas.formula: \text{If } \angle AOB = 2\theta \text{ at center, then } \angle APB = \theta \text{ at circumference}
formulas.explanation: The angle at the center is twice any angle at the circumference subtended by the same chord

formulas.title: Cyclic Quadrilateral
formulas.formula: \text{In cyclic quadrilateral } ABCD, \\ \angle A + \angle C = 180^\circ \text{ and } \angle B + \angle D = 180^\circ
formulas.explanation: Opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are supplementary

realworld.title: Satellite Communication
realworld.description: The angle subtended by the Earth's surface at a satellite determines the coverage area. Communication satellites are placed in geostationary orbit where they subtend specific angles to ensure continuous coverage of particular regions.

topics.name: Perpendicular from the Centre to a Chord

notes.title: Key Properties
points: The perpendicular from the center of a circle to a chord bisects the chord
The converse is also true: The line joining the center of a circle to the midpoint of a chord is perpendicular to the chord
The shortest distance from the center to a chord is the length of the perpendicular from the center to that chord
This property is used to find the length of a chord when the distance from the center is known

notes.title: Applications
points: Used in constructing tangents to a circle from an external point
Helps in finding the radius when chord length and distance from center are known
Essential in solving problems involving intersecting chords and their properties

formulas.title: Chord Length Formula
formulas.formula: \text{If } OM \perp AB, \text{ then } AM = MB = \frac{1}{2}AB \\ \text{and } AB = 2\sqrt{r^2 - d^2}
formulas.explanation: Where r is the radius, d is the perpendicular distance from center to chord

realworld.title: Architectural Design
realworld.description: The principle of perpendicular from center to chord is used in designing circular arches and domes, ensuring structural stability by maintaining equal distribution of forces along the chord.

topics.name: Equal Chords and their Distances from Centre

notes.title: Fundamental Properties
points: Equal chords of a circle are equidistant from the center
Chords that are equidistant from the center are equal in length
The length of the chord decreases as its distance from the center increases
The longest chord of a circle is its diameter, which passes through the center

notes.title: Theorems
points: Theorem: Equal chords subtend equal angles at the center
Theorem: If the angles subtended by two chords at the center are equal, then the chords are equal
Theorem: Of any two chords of a circle, the one which is nearer to the center is longer

formulas.title: Distance-Chord Relationship
formulas.formula: \text{For two chords } AB \text{ and } CD, \\ \text{if } AB = CD, \text{ then } OM = ON \\ \text{where } OM \perp AB, ON \perp CD
formulas.explanation: Equal chords are equidistant from the center

realworld.title: Mechanical Engineering
realworld.description: In gear systems, the principle of equal chords is used to design gear teeth that are equally spaced around a circular gear, ensuring smooth transmission of motion and force.

notes.title: Properties
points: A quadrilateral is called cyclic if all its four vertices lie on a circle
The sum of either pair of opposite angles is 180°
If a side of a cyclic quadrilateral is produced, the exterior angle so formed is equal to the interior opposite angle
The product of the diagonals is equal to the sum of the products of opposite sides (Ptolemy's theorem)

notes.title: Theorems and Tests
points: Theorem: The opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are supplementary
Converse: If the sum of any pair of opposite angles of a quadrilateral is 180°, then the quadrilateral is cyclic
Test: If one side of a quadrilateral subtends equal angles at the other two vertices, then the quadrilateral is cyclic

formulas.title: Ptolemy's Theorem
formulas.formula: \text{For cyclic quadrilateral } ABCD, \\ AC \times BD = AB \times CD + AD \times BC
formulas.explanation: The product of the diagonals equals the sum of products of opposite sides

realworld.title: Navigation Systems
realworld.description: Cyclic quadrilaterals are used in navigation and surveying to determine unknown positions. By measuring angles from known points, the properties of cyclic quadrilaterals help in triangulation methods for precise location determination.

topics.name: Area of a Triangle by Heron's Formula

notes.title: Introduction to Heron's Formula
points: Heron's formula allows us to calculate the area of a triangle when all three sides are known
It's particularly useful when the height of the triangle is not known or difficult to determine
The formula is named after Hero of Alexandria, a Greek engineer and mathematician
It's also known as Hero's formula

notes.title: Understanding the Formula
points: First, calculate the semi-perimeter (s) of the triangle
Then apply Heron's formula using the semi-perimeter and the lengths of the three sides
The formula works for all types of triangles: equilateral, isosceles, and scalene
It's especially useful for scalene triangles where other area formulas might be complex to apply

formulas.title: Heron's Formula
formulas.explanation: a, b, c are the lengths of the sides of the triangle, and s is the semi-perimeter

formulas.title: Area of Equilateral Triangle
formulas.explanation: Special case of Heron's formula when all sides are equal (a = b = c)

realworld.title: Land Surveying
realworld.description: Surveyors use Heron's formula to calculate the area of triangular plots of land when direct measurement of height is impractical, especially in uneven terrains.

topics.name: Application in Finding Areas of Quadrilaterals

notes.title: Dividing Quadrilaterals
points: Any quadrilateral can be divided into two triangles by drawing one of its diagonals
Heron's formula can be applied to both triangles separately
The total area of the quadrilateral is the sum of the areas of these two triangles
This method works for all types of quadrilaterals, including irregular ones

notes.title: Special Cases
points: For a rhombus or kite, the area can be found using the formula: (1/2) × d₁ × d₂
However, if the side lengths are known but not the diagonals, Heron's formula can be used by dividing the quadrilateral into two triangles
For cyclic quadrilaterals, Brahmagupta's formula (an extension of Heron's formula) can be used

formulas.title: Area of Quadrilateral using Heron's Formula
formulas.explanation: a, b, c, d are the sides of the quadrilateral, d₁ is the diagonal

formulas.title: Brahmagupta's Formula
formulas.explanation: For cyclic quadrilaterals only (quadrilaterals that can be inscribed in a circle)

realworld.title: Architecture and Construction
realworld.description: Architects use Heron's formula to calculate the area of irregularly shaped rooms or plots by dividing them into triangles, especially when dealing with non-rectangular floor plans or land parcels.

notes.title: Understanding Spheres
points: A sphere is a perfectly round three-dimensional object where every point on its surface is equidistant from its center.
Examples include balls, globes, and planets like Earth.
The surface area is the total area covered by the outer surface of the sphere.

notes.title: Key Properties
points: A sphere has no edges or vertices.
The distance from the center to any point on the surface is called the radius (r).
The diameter is twice the radius (d = 2r).

formulas.title: Surface Area Formula
formulas.explanation: The surface area (A) of a sphere with radius r is four times pi times the square of the radius.

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Companies use the surface area formula to calculate the amount of material needed to make basketballs, globes, or any spherical object.

topics.name: Volume of a Right Circular Cone

notes.title: Cone Basics
points: A right circular cone has a circular base and a vertex (apex) directly above the center of the base.
The height (h) is the perpendicular distance from the base to the vertex.
The slant height (l) is the distance from the vertex to any point on the circular edge of the base.

notes.title: Key Relationships
points: The relationship between radius (r), height (h), and slant height (l) is given by: l² = r² + h²
The base area of the cone is πr².
The volume represents the space occupied by the cone.

formulas.title: Volume Formula
formulas.explanation: The volume (V) of a cone is one-third the product of the base area (πr²) and the height (h).

formulas.title: Slant Height Formula
formulas.explanation: Relates the slant height (l) to the radius (r) and height (h) of the cone.

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Civil engineers use the cone volume formula to calculate the amount of concrete needed for conical structures like traffic cones or decorative elements in architecture.

notes.title: Understanding Volume
points: Volume measures the space occupied by a three-dimensional object.
For a sphere, it represents the amount of air inside a ball or the capacity of a spherical container.
The volume increases rapidly with the radius due to the cubic relationship.

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: The volume depends only on the radius of the sphere.
A sphere has the largest volume-to-surface-area ratio of any shape.
The formula relates the volume to the cube of the radius.

formulas.title: Volume Formula
formulas.explanation: The volume (V) of a sphere is four-thirds times pi times the cube of the radius (r).

formulas.title: Relationship with Diameter
formulas.explanation: Alternative formula using diameter (d) instead of radius.

realworld.title: Meteorology
realworld.description: Scientists calculate the volume of raindrops (which are approximately spherical) to understand precipitation patterns and water distribution in weather systems.

realworld.title: Medicine
realworld.description: The volume formula helps in determining the correct dosage of medication in spherical capsules based on their size.

notes.title: Introduction to Matter
points: Matter is anything that occupies space and has mass.
Everything around us, including air, water, and even our bodies, is made up of matter.
Matter is made up of tiny particles called atoms and molecules.
These particles are in a state of continuous motion and have space between them.

notes.title: Characteristics of Particles of Matter
points: Particles of matter are very small in size (nanometer scale).
They have spaces between them (intermolecular spaces).
They are in continuous motion (kinetic energy).
They attract each other (intermolecular forces).
The force of attraction varies in different states of matter.

formulas.title: Density
formulas.explanation: Density is a characteristic property of a substance that helps in its identification.

formulas.title: Pressure-Volume Relationship
formulas.explanation: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a gas is inversely proportional to its volume at constant temperature.

realworld.title: Hot Air Balloons
realworld.description: The working of hot air balloons is based on the principle that matter expands on heating. When air inside the balloon is heated, it becomes less dense than the surrounding cooler air, causing the balloon to rise.

notes.title: Solid State
points: Definite shape and volume.
Particles are closely packed in a fixed arrangement.
Strong intermolecular forces.
Particles can only vibrate about their mean position (lowest kinetic energy).
Examples: Ice, wood, iron, etc.

notes.title: Liquid State
points: Definite volume but no fixed shape (takes the shape of container).
Particles are less closely packed than solids.
Weaker intermolecular forces than solids.
Particles can move, slide, and flow (moderate kinetic energy).
Examples: Water, oil, milk, etc.

notes.title: Gaseous State
points: No definite shape or volume (fills the container completely).
Particles are far apart with maximum space between them.
Negligible intermolecular forces.
Particles move randomly at high speeds (highest kinetic energy).
Examples: Oxygen, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, etc.

notes.title: Plasma and Bose-Einstein Condensate (BEC)
points: Plasma is the fourth state of matter (ionized gas at very high temperatures).
Found in stars, lightning, and neon signs.
BEC is the fifth state formed at temperatures close to absolute zero.
In BEC, atoms lose their individual identity and behave as a single quantum state.

formulas.title: Charles's Law
formulas.explanation: The volume of a fixed mass of gas is directly proportional to its absolute temperature at constant pressure.

formulas.title: Gay-Lussac's Law
formulas.explanation: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is directly proportional to its absolute temperature at constant volume.

realworld.title: Pressure Cooker
realworld.description: In a pressure cooker, the boiling point of water increases with increasing pressure, allowing food to cook faster at higher temperatures.

realworld.title: Liquid-in-Glass Thermometer
realworld.description: The working of a thermometer is based on the principle that liquids expand on heating. The expansion of mercury or alcohol in the narrow tube indicates the temperature.

notes.title: Understanding Evaporation
points: Process by which a liquid changes into vapor at any temperature below its boiling point.
A surface phenomenon that occurs only at the surface of the liquid.
Cooling process as particles with higher kinetic energy escape, reducing the average kinetic energy of remaining particles.
Rate of evaporation increases with: increase in surface area, increase in temperature, decrease in humidity, and increase in wind speed.

notes.title: Factors Affecting Evaporation
points: Temperature: Higher temperature increases the rate of evaporation.
Surface Area: Larger surface area increases the rate of evaporation.
Humidity: Lower humidity increases the rate of evaporation.
Wind Speed: Higher wind speed increases the rate of evaporation by removing water vapor from the surface.

notes.title: Evaporation vs. Boiling
points: Evaporation occurs at all temperatures, while boiling occurs at a fixed temperature (boiling point).
Evaporation is a surface phenomenon, while boiling is a bulk phenomenon.
Evaporation is a slow process, while boiling is a rapid process.
Evaporation causes cooling, while boiling requires continuous heating.

formulas.title: Relative Humidity
formulas.explanation: The amount of water vapor present in air expressed as a percentage of the amount needed for saturation at the same temperature.

formulas.title: Cooling by Evaporation
formulas.explanation: The heat energy (Q) required for evaporation is the product of the mass of the substance (m) and its latent heat of vaporization (L_v).

realworld.title: Sweating
realworld.description: When we sweat, the water from our skin evaporates by taking the required latent heat from our body, thus cooling us down.

realworld.title: Earthen Pots
realworld.description: Water kept in earthen pots becomes cool because the water seeps through the porous walls and evaporates, taking away the latent heat from the remaining water.

realworld.title: Drying Clothes
realworld.concept: Effect of Surface Area and Wind
realworld.description: Clothes dry faster when spread out (increased surface area) and when there is wind (removes water vapor from the surface).

notes.title: Understanding Mixtures
points: A mixture is a combination of two or more pure substances (elements or compounds) that are not chemically combined.
The components of a mixture can be separated by physical methods like filtration, evaporation, etc.
The properties of a mixture are the same as those of its individual components.

notes.title: Types of Mixtures
points: Homogeneous Mixtures: Uniform composition throughout, e.g., salt solution, air, sugar solution.
Heterogeneous Mixtures: Non-uniform composition, e.g., sand and salt, oil and water, soil.
Colloidal Solutions: Mixtures where the particle size is between 1-1000 nm, e.g., milk, fog, smoke.
Suspensions: Heterogeneous mixtures where solid particles are dispersed in a liquid, e.g., muddy water, chalk-water mixture.

formulas.title: Mass Percentage
formulas.explanation: Used to express the concentration of a component in a mixture.

formulas.title: Volume Percentage
formulas.explanation: Used to express the concentration of a liquid in a liquid solution.

realworld.title: Air Quality Monitoring
realworld.description: Air is a homogeneous mixture of gases (nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, etc.). Air quality monitoring stations analyze the composition of air to check pollution levels.

notes.title: Solutions
points: Homogeneous mixtures of two or more substances.
Particle size < 1 nm, cannot be seen with naked eye.
Do not scatter light (Tyndall effect not observed).
Stable and do not settle down on standing.
Examples: Salt solution, sugar solution, air.

notes.title: Suspensions
points: Heterogeneous mixtures where solid particles are dispersed in a liquid.
Particle size > 1000 nm, visible to naked eye.
Show Tyndall effect.
Unstable and settle down on standing.
Can be separated by filtration.
Examples: Muddy water, chalk-water mixture, sand in water.

notes.title: Colloids
points: Heterogeneous mixtures where particle size is between 1-1000 nm.
Particles are not visible to naked eye but can be seen under a microscope.
Show Tyndall effect.
Stable and do not settle down on standing.
Cannot be separated by filtration but can be separated by centrifugation.
Examples: Milk, blood, smoke, fog, jelly, butter.

formulas.title: Concentration of Solution
formulas.formula: \text{Concentration} = \frac{\text{Mass of solute}}{\text{Volume of solution in liters}} \text{ (g/L)}
formulas.explanation: Expresses the amount of solute dissolved in a given volume of solution.

formulas.title: Dilution Formula
formulas.explanation: Used to calculate the new concentration or volume when a solution is diluted.

realworld.title: Milk Processing
realworld.description: Milk is a colloid where fat globules are dispersed in water. The process of homogenization breaks down the fat globules to prevent cream from separating.

notes.title: Physical Changes
points: No new substance is formed.
The change is reversible.
No change in the chemical composition of the substance.
Only physical properties like shape, size, state change.
Examples: Melting of ice, boiling of water, tearing of paper.

notes.title: Chemical Changes
points: New substances with different properties are formed.
The change is usually irreversible.
Involves change in the chemical composition of the substance.
Energy is usually absorbed or released (heat, light, sound).
Examples: Burning of paper, rusting of iron, cooking of food.

notes.title: Characteristics of Chemical Changes
points: Evolution of gas
Formation of precipitate
Change in color
Change in temperature
Change in state (sometimes)

formulas.title: Heat Energy in Physical Changes
formulas.explanation: Q = heat energy, m = mass, L = latent heat. Used to calculate energy involved in phase changes.

formulas.title: Chemical Reaction
formulas.explanation: General form of a chemical reaction showing the conversion of reactants to products.

realworld.title: Food Digestion
realworld.description: The process of digestion involves chemical changes where complex food molecules are broken down into simpler substances by enzymes in our body.

notes.title: Elements
points: Pure substances made up of only one type of atom.
Cannot be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means.
Represented by symbols (e.g., H, O, Na, Fe).
Classified as metals, non-metals, and metalloids.
Examples: Gold (Au), Oxygen (O), Iron (Fe).

notes.title: Compounds
points: Pure substances made up of two or more elements chemically combined in a fixed ratio.
Can be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means.
Have properties different from their constituent elements.
Represented by chemical formulas (e.g., H₂O, CO₂, NaCl).
Examples: Water (H₂O), Carbon dioxide (CO₂), Common salt (NaCl).

notes.title: Differences Between Elements and Compounds
points: Elements consist of only one type of atom; compounds consist of two or more types of atoms.
Elements cannot be broken down; compounds can be broken down by chemical means.
Properties of elements are different from compounds formed by them.
The ratio of elements in a compound is fixed.

formulas.title: Chemical Formula
formulas.explanation: Represents the composition of a compound in terms of symbols of elements and their proportions.

formulas.title: Law of Definite Proportions
formulas.formula: \text{In a compound, elements are always combined in the same proportion by mass.}
formulas.explanation: Also known as Proust's law, it states that a chemical compound always contains exactly the same proportion of elements by mass.

realworld.title: Water Purification
realworld.description: Water (H₂O) is a compound made of hydrogen and oxygen in a 2:1 ratio. The process of water purification involves removing impurities while maintaining the chemical composition of water.

notes.title: Law of Conservation of Mass
points: Proposed by Antoine Lavoisier in 1789.
States that mass can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction.
Total mass of reactants = Total mass of products.
Verified by Landolt's experiment using H-type tube.

notes.title: Law of Definite Proportions
points: Proposed by Joseph Proust in 1799.
A chemical compound always contains the same elements combined together in the same proportion by mass.
Example: Pure water (H₂O) always has hydrogen and oxygen in 1:8 mass ratio.
Also known as Proust's law or Law of Constant Composition.

notes.title: Law of Multiple Proportions
points: Proposed by John Dalton in 1803.
When two elements combine to form more than one compound, the masses of one element that combine with a fixed mass of the other element are in the ratio of small whole numbers.
Example: Carbon and oxygen form CO and CO₂. The mass ratio of oxygen combining with fixed mass of carbon is 1:2.

formulas.title: Mass Conservation
formulas.explanation: The total mass remains constant in a chemical reaction.

formulas.title: Definite Proportion
formulas.formula: \text{Mass ratio is constant for a compound}
formulas.explanation: For water (H₂O), H:O mass ratio is always 1:8.

realworld.title: Rocket Propulsion
realworld.description: The principle of conservation of mass is crucial in rocket science where the mass of fuel burned equals the mass of exhaust gases produced, maintaining the total mass balance.

notes.title: Chemical Symbols and Valency
points: Symbols represent elements (e.g., H for Hydrogen, O for Oxygen).
Valency is the combining capacity of an element.
For writing formulae, we use criss-cross method where valencies are exchanged.
Example: For Aluminium Oxide (Al³⁺ and O²⁻), the formula is Al₂O₃.

notes.title: Rules for Writing Formulae
points: Write symbols with positive element first (metal before non-metal).
Write valency above each symbol.
Cross the valencies to get the number of atoms.
If the valencies have common factor, divide by it.
If the number of atoms is 1, it is not written.

notes.title: Types of Chemical Formulae
points: Molecular Formula: Shows actual number of atoms (e.g., H₂O).
Empirical Formula: Simplest ratio of atoms (e.g., CH₂O for glucose).
Structural Formula: Shows arrangement of atoms (e.g., H-O-H for water).

formulas.title: Criss-Cross Method
formulas.explanation: Exchange the valencies and write as subscripts.

formulas.title: Polyatomic Ions
formulas.explanation: Groups of atoms carrying a charge, treated as single units in formulae.

realworld.title: Pharmaceutical Industry
realworld.description: Accurate chemical formulae are essential in drug manufacturing to ensure the correct composition and dosage of medications.

notes.title: Atomic and Molecular Mass
points: Atomic mass is the mass of one atom of an element in atomic mass units (u).
Molecular mass is the sum of atomic masses of all atoms in a molecule.
Example: H₂O = (2×1) + 16 = 18 u.
Gram atomic/molecular mass is the mass in grams numerically equal to atomic/molecular mass.

notes.title: Mole Concept
points: One mole is the amount of substance that contains 6.022 × 10²³ particles (Avogadro's number).
Molar mass is the mass of one mole of a substance in grams.
Number of moles = Given mass / Molar mass.
At STP, one mole of any gas occupies 22.4 L.

notes.title: Percentage Composition
points: Mass percentage of an element = (Mass of element in compound / Molar mass of compound) × 100.
Useful in determining empirical and molecular formulae.
Helps in analyzing the purity of a compound.

formulas.title: Number of Moles
formulas.explanation: Relates mass of a substance to number of moles.

formulas.title: Number of Particles
formulas.explanation: Where n = number of moles, N_A = Avogadro's number (6.022 × 10²³).

formulas.title: Percentage Composition
formulas.explanation: n = number of atoms of the element in one molecule.

realworld.title: Fertilizer Production
realworld.description: The mole concept is used to calculate the exact amounts of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium needed in fertilizers to provide optimal nutrition for different crops.

realworld.title: Airbag Deployment
realworld.description: The volume of gas needed to inflate an airbag is calculated using the mole concept and the fact that one mole of any gas occupies 22.4 L at STP.

notes.title: Discovery of Subatomic Particles
points: Electrons (e⁻): Discovered by J.J. Thomson in 1897 through cathode ray experiment.
Protons (p⁺): Discovered by E. Goldstein in 1886 through anode ray experiment.
Neutrons (n⁰): Discovered by James Chadwick in 1932 through alpha particle scattering experiment.
Electrons are negatively charged, protons are positively charged, and neutrons are neutral.

notes.title: Properties of Subatomic Particles
points: Electron: Mass = 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg, Charge = -1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C
Proton: Mass = 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg, Charge = +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C
Neutron: Mass ≈ 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg, No charge
Protons and neutrons are present in the nucleus, while electrons revolve around it.

formulas.title: Charge to Mass Ratio
formulas.explanation: Specific charge of an electron, determined by J.J. Thomson.

realworld.title: Cathode Ray Tubes
realworld.description: Old television and computer monitors used cathode ray tubes where beams of electrons are deflected by electric and magnetic fields to create images on a fluorescent screen.

topics.name: Models of an Atom (Thomson, Rutherford, Bohr)

notes.title: Thomson's Plum Pudding Model (1904)
points: Atom as a positively charged sphere with electrons embedded in it.
Also called the watermelon model.
Failed to explain the results of the alpha particle scattering experiment.

notes.title: Rutherford's Nuclear Model (1911)
points: Based on the gold foil experiment (alpha particle scattering experiment).
Most of the atom's mass and positive charge is concentrated in a tiny nucleus.
Electrons revolve around the nucleus in circular paths.
Most of the atom is empty space.
Failed to explain the stability of atoms and the line spectrum of hydrogen.

notes.title: Bohr's Model (1913)
points: Electrons move around the nucleus in fixed circular orbits called energy levels or shells (K, L, M, N...).
Each orbit has a fixed energy; no energy is radiated in stationary orbits.
Energy is absorbed or emitted when electrons jump between orbits.
Explained the stability of atoms and the line spectrum of hydrogen.

formulas.title: Bohr's Energy Levels
formulas.explanation: Energy of an electron in the nth orbit of hydrogen atom.

realworld.title: Atomic Clocks
realworld.description: Atomic clocks use the vibrations of electrons in cesium or rubidium atoms to keep time with extreme precision, based on the principles of quantum mechanics.

notes.title: Discovery and Properties of Neutrons
points: Discovered by James Chadwick in 1932.
Electrically neutral particles with mass slightly greater than that of protons.
Present in the nucleus of all atoms except hydrogen-1.
Number of neutrons = Mass number - Atomic number.

notes.title: Electron Distribution in Orbits
points: Electrons are distributed in different shells around the nucleus.
Maximum number of electrons in a shell = 2n² (where n is the shell number).
K shell (n=1): 2 electrons, L shell (n=2): 8 electrons, M shell (n=3): 18 electrons, etc.
Outermost shell cannot have more than 8 electrons (Octet rule).

notes.title: Valence Electrons
points: Electrons present in the outermost shell of an atom.
Determine the chemical properties and reactivity of elements.
Atoms tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to achieve a stable octet configuration.

formulas.title: Maximum Electrons in a Shell
formulas.explanation: Where n is the principal quantum number (shell number).

realworld.title: Nuclear Power Plants
realworld.description: In nuclear reactors, neutrons are slowed down (moderated) by materials like water or graphite to sustain a controlled nuclear chain reaction.

topics.name: Valency, Atomic Number, and Mass Number

notes.title: Atomic Number (Z)
points: Number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
Also equals the number of electrons in a neutral atom.
Unique for each element and determines its position in the periodic table.

notes.title: Mass Number (A)
points: Sum of the number of protons and neutrons in an atom's nucleus.
A = Number of protons + Number of neutrons.
Atoms of the same element can have different mass numbers (isotopes).

notes.title: Valency
points: Combining capacity of an element.
Equal to the number of electrons an atom can lose, gain, or share to achieve a stable configuration.
For metals: Valency = Number of valence electrons.
For non-metals: Valency = 8 - Number of valence electrons.

formulas.title: Mass Number
formulas.explanation: Where A = Mass number, Z = Atomic number, N = Number of neutrons.

realworld.title: Medical Imaging
realworld.description: Isotopes like Technetium-99m are used in medical imaging to diagnose various conditions, taking advantage of their specific atomic properties.

notes.title: Isotopes
points: Atoms of the same element having the same atomic number but different mass numbers.
Same number of protons but different number of neutrons.
Similar chemical properties but different physical properties.
Examples: ¹H, ²H (Deuterium), ³H (Tritium) are isotopes of hydrogen.

notes.title: Isobars
points: Atoms of different elements having the same mass number but different atomic numbers.
Different number of protons and neutrons, but sum is same.
Different chemical and physical properties.
Example: ⁴⁰₁₈Ar and ⁴⁰₂₀Ca have same mass number (40) but different atomic numbers.

notes.title: Applications of Isotopes
points: Carbon-14 dating: Used in archaeology to determine the age of ancient artifacts.
Cobalt-60: Used in cancer treatment (radiotherapy).
Iodine-131: Used in the treatment of thyroid disorders.
Uranium-235: Used as nuclear fuel in nuclear reactors.

formulas.title: Average Atomic Mass
formulas.explanation: Used to calculate the weighted average mass of all naturally occurring isotopes of an element.

realworld.title: Carbon Dating
realworld.description: Archaeologists use the known half-life of Carbon-14 (5730 years) to determine the age of organic materials, as the ratio of C-14 to C-12 changes over time through radioactive decay.

realworld.title: Nuclear Medicine
realworld.description: Technetium-99m, a radioactive isotope, is used in over 80% of nuclear medicine procedures worldwide for diagnostic imaging of various organs and tissues.

notes.title: Structure of Plasma Membrane
points: Also called the cell membrane, it is the outermost covering of animal cells.
Composed of lipids (phospholipids) and proteins (fluid mosaic model).
Semi-permeable in nature, allowing only certain substances to pass through.
Maintains cell shape and protects the cell from its surroundings.

notes.title: Functions of Plasma Membrane
points: Regulates the movement of substances in and out of the cell (selective permeability).
Protects the cell from harmful substances.
Helps in cell recognition and communication.
Maintains the shape and structure of the cell.

notes.title: Cell Wall
points: Present in plant cells, fungi, and some bacteria (absent in animal cells).
Made up of cellulose in plants (chitin in fungi and peptidoglycan in bacteria).
Provides structural support and rigidity to the cell.
Fully permeable, allowing all substances to pass through.

formulas.title: Osmosis
formulas.explanation: Describes the movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane.

realworld.title: Desalination Plants
realworld.description: Uses semi-permeable membranes to remove salt and impurities from seawater, making it drinkable.

notes.title: Nucleus: The Control Center
points: Discovered by Robert Brown in 1831.
Double membrane-bound organelle containing genetic material (DNA).
Controls all cellular activities and contains the hereditary information.
Nucleolus inside the nucleus is the site of ribosome formation.

notes.title: Chromosomes and Genes
points: Thread-like structures made of DNA and proteins.
Carry genes that determine hereditary characteristics.
Human cells have 46 chromosomes (23 pairs).
Genes are segments of DNA that code for specific proteins.

notes.title: Cytoplasm
points: Jelly-like substance present between the cell membrane and nucleus.
Composed of water, salts, and organic compounds.
Site of many chemical reactions of the cell (metabolism).
Contains all the cell organelles suspended in it.

formulas.title: Nucleic Acid Base Pairing
formulas.explanation: Complementary base pairing in DNA, where A pairs with T and G pairs with C.

realworld.title: Genetic Testing
realworld.description: Used in medicine to identify genetic disorders and determine a person's biological parents through DNA fingerprinting.

notes.title: Mitochondria
points: Known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'.
Site of cellular respiration and ATP production.
Double membrane-bound with inner membrane folded into cristae.
Contains its own DNA and ribosomes (semiautonomous).

notes.title: Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)
points: Network of membrane-bound tubules and flattened sacs (cisternae).
Two types: Rough ER (with ribosomes) and Smooth ER (without ribosomes).
RER helps in protein synthesis and transport.
SER is involved in lipid synthesis and detoxification.

notes.title: Golgi Apparatus
points: Discovered by Camillo Golgi in 1898.
Stacks of flattened membrane-bound sacs (cisternae).
Modifies, sorts, and packages proteins and lipids for secretion.
Forms lysosomes and secretory vesicles.

notes.title: Lysosomes
points: Called 'suicide bags' of the cell.
Membrane-bound vesicles containing digestive enzymes.
Digest worn-out cell parts, food particles, and foreign invaders.
Help in cell renewal and removal of cellular debris.

notes.title: Plastids (in plant cells)
points: Double membrane-bound organelles containing pigments.
Types: Chloroplasts (green, for photosynthesis), Chromoplasts (colored), and Leucoplasts (colorless, for storage).
Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and are the site of photosynthesis.

notes.title: Vacuoles
points: Membrane-bound sacs for storage and waste disposal.
Large central vacuole in plant cells maintains turgor pressure.
Stores water, salts, sugars, and pigments in plant cells.
Smaller and more numerous in animal cells.

notes.title: Ribosomes
points: Small, dense, granular structures without a membrane.
Composed of RNA and proteins.
Site of protein synthesis (translation).
Found either free in the cytoplasm or attached to the ER.

formulas.title: Photosynthesis
formulas.explanation: Process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy in chloroplasts.

formulas.title: Cellular Respiration
formulas.explanation: Process by which cells break down glucose to produce energy (ATP) in mitochondria.

realworld.title: Mitochondrial Diseases
realworld.description: Conditions like MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes) occur due to mitochondrial dysfunction, affecting energy production in cells.

realworld.title: Pharmaceutical Production
realworld.description: Bacteria are genetically modified to produce human insulin and other therapeutic proteins using their ribosomes and protein synthesis machinery.

realworld.title: Food Preservation
realworld.description: Jams and pickles are preserved using concentrated sugar or salt solutions that cause plasmolysis in bacterial cells, preventing food spoilage.

notes.title: Scalar and Vector Quantities
points: Scalar quantities have only magnitude (e.g., mass, distance, speed, time).
Vector quantities have both magnitude and direction (e.g., displacement, velocity, force, acceleration).
Speed is a scalar quantity (how fast an object is moving).
Velocity is a vector quantity (speed in a given direction).

notes.title: Distance and Displacement
points: Distance: Total path length covered by an object (scalar quantity).
Displacement: Shortest distance between initial and final positions (vector quantity).
Displacement can be zero even when distance is not zero (circular motion).
Displacement can be negative (depends on the chosen coordinate system).

notes.title: Speed and Velocity
points: Average Speed = Total distance travelled / Total time taken
Average Velocity = Total displacement / Total time taken
Instantaneous speed/velocity is the speed/velocity at a particular instant of time.
Velocity can be positive, negative, or zero depending on direction.

formulas.title: Average Speed
formulas.explanation: Calculates the total distance covered per unit time.

formulas.title: Average Velocity
formulas.explanation: Calculates the displacement per unit time, considering direction.

realworld.title: GPS Navigation
realworld.description: GPS systems calculate your position and velocity to provide real-time navigation, using vector mathematics to determine the most efficient route to your destination.

notes.title: First Equation of Motion
points: v = u + at
Where:
v = final velocity
u = initial velocity
a = acceleration
t = time
Derived from the definition of acceleration (a = (v-u)/t).

notes.title: Second Equation of Motion
points: s = ut + ½at²
Where s = displacement
Gives the displacement of an object under constant acceleration.
When initial velocity (u) is zero, equation becomes s = ½at².

notes.title: Third Equation of Motion
points: v² = u² + 2as
Relates final velocity, initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement.
Does not involve time (t).
Useful when time is not given in the problem.

notes.title: Uniform and Non-uniform Motion
points: Uniform motion: Equal distances in equal intervals of time (constant speed).
Non-uniform motion: Unequal distances in equal intervals of time (changing speed).
Accelerated motion: When velocity changes with time.
Retardation/Deceleration: Negative acceleration (slowing down).

formulas.title: First Equation of Motion
formulas.explanation: Relates final velocity to initial velocity, acceleration, and time.

formulas.title: Second Equation of Motion
formulas.explanation: Relates displacement to initial velocity, time, and acceleration.

formulas.title: Third Equation of Motion
formulas.explanation: Relates final velocity to initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement.

realworld.title: Car Safety
realworld.description: The equations of motion are used to calculate stopping distances for vehicles, considering reaction time and braking distance, which is crucial for road safety and speed limit determination.

realworld.title: Sports Science
realworld.description: Athletes and coaches use these equations to analyze and improve performance in sports like javelin throw, long jump, and basketball.

notes.title: Characteristics of Circular Motion
points: Motion of an object along the circumference of a circle with constant speed but changing velocity.
Direction of velocity is always tangent to the circular path.
Continuous change in direction means continuous change in velocity (acceleration).
Centripetal force acts towards the center, causing centripetal acceleration.

notes.title: Centripetal Force and Acceleration
points: Centripetal acceleration (a_c) = v²/r (directed towards the center).
Centripetal force (F_c) = mv²/r (required to keep the object moving in a circle).
Centripetal force is not a new kind of force; it's provided by forces like tension, friction, or gravity.
Examples: Moon orbiting Earth, car taking a curve, spinning a bucket of water.

notes.title: Angular Displacement and Velocity
points: Angular displacement (θ) = arc length/radius (measured in radians).
Angular velocity (ω) = θ/t (radians per second).
Relation between linear velocity (v) and angular velocity (ω): v = rω.
Time period (T) = 2π/ω, Frequency (f) = 1/T.

formulas.title: Centripetal Acceleration
formulas.explanation: Acceleration directed towards the center of the circular path.

formulas.title: Centripetal Force
formulas.explanation: Net force required to keep an object moving in a circular path.

formulas.title: Relation between Linear and Angular Velocity
formulas.explanation: Connects linear velocity (v) with angular velocity (ω) and radius (r).

realworld.title: Amusement Park Rides
realworld.description: Roller coasters and other rides use principles of circular motion to create thrilling experiences while ensuring safety through careful calculation of forces and speeds.

realworld.title: Satellite Orbits
realworld.description: Artificial satellites maintain their orbits around Earth due to the balance between gravitational force (acting as centripetal force) and their tangential velocity, following the principles of uniform circular motion.

realworld.title: Washing Machine
realworld.description: The spin cycle uses circular motion to create a centripetal force that pulls water out of clothes, making them drier at the end of the wash cycle.

notes.title: Law of Inertia
points: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
Also known as the Law of Inertia.
Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion.
Mass is a measure of an object's inertia.

notes.title: Examples of Inertia
points: Passengers lurch forward when a moving bus stops suddenly.
Dust particles fall off a carpet when beaten.
A person in a moving car continues to move forward when the car stops suddenly (reason for seat belts).
A coin placed on a card over a glass stays in place when the card is flicked quickly.

formulas.title: Newton's First Law
formulas.explanation: When the net force on an object is zero, its acceleration is zero (it maintains constant velocity).

realworld.title: Car Safety Features
realworld.description: Seat belts and airbags are designed to work with Newton's First Law by preventing passengers from continuing their motion during sudden stops or collisions.

notes.title: Understanding Inertia
points: Inertia is the natural tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion or rest.
Directly related to the mass of the object - more mass means more inertia.
Three types: Inertia of rest, Inertia of motion, and Inertia of direction.
Explains why it's harder to push a truck than a bicycle.

notes.title: Mass vs. Weight
points: Mass is the amount of matter in an object (scalar, measured in kg).
Weight is the force of gravity on an object (vector, measured in N).
Mass is constant, while weight changes with gravity (e.g., on the Moon).
W = m × g (Weight = mass × acceleration due to gravity).

formulas.title: Weight Formula
formulas.explanation: Weight is the product of mass (m) and acceleration due to gravity (g ≈ 9.8 m/s² on Earth).

realworld.title: Space Exploration
realworld.description: Astronauts in orbit are weightless (free-fall) but their mass remains the same, which is why they need exercise equipment to prevent muscle atrophy in microgravity.

notes.title: Momentum Basics
points: Momentum (p) is the product of an object's mass and velocity (p = m × v).
Vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction).
SI unit: kg·m/s.
A moving object has momentum; a stationary object has zero momentum.

notes.title: Law of Conservation of Momentum
points: In the absence of external forces, the total momentum of a system remains constant.
For a collision between two objects: m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂.
Applies to both elastic and inelastic collisions.
Explains rocket propulsion and recoil of guns.

notes.title: Newton's Third Law
points: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
Action and reaction forces act on different objects.
Examples: Walking (pushing ground backward, ground pushes you forward), rocket propulsion.

formulas.title: Momentum
formulas.explanation: Momentum is the product of mass and velocity.

formulas.title: Conservation of Momentum
formulas.explanation: Total momentum before collision equals total momentum after collision in an isolated system.

formulas.title: Newton's Second Law
formulas.explanation: Force equals the rate of change of momentum, which equals mass times acceleration when mass is constant.

realworld.title: Car Crashes
realworld.description: Crumple zones in cars increase the time of impact during a collision, reducing the force experienced by passengers (Δp = F × Δt).

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: In sports like billiards or cricket, understanding momentum helps players predict ball trajectories after collisions.

realworld.title: Space Travel
realworld.description: Rockets work on the principle of conservation of momentum, where the backward expulsion of gases propels the rocket forward.

notes.title: Meristematic Tissues
points: Composed of actively dividing cells responsible for plant growth.
Characteristics: Thin cell walls, dense cytoplasm, prominent nuclei, and lack vacuoles.
Types based on location:
- Apical meristem (tips of roots and stems)
- Lateral meristem (cambium, increases girth)
- Intercalary meristem (base of leaves/internodes, increases length).

notes.title: Permanent Tissues
points: Differentiated cells that have lost the ability to divide.
Simple Permanent Tissues:
- Parenchyma: Thin-walled, living cells for storage and photosynthesis.
- Collenchyma: Thickened at corners, provides mechanical support to growing parts.
- Sclerenchyma: Thick, lignified walls, dead cells providing strength.
Complex Permanent Tissues:
- Xylem: Conducts water and minerals (tracheids, vessels, xylem parenchyma, xylem fibers).
- Phloem: Conducts food (sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem parenchyma, phloem fibers).

formulas.title: Growth Rate in Plants
formulas.explanation: Plant growth occurs through these three processes in sequence.

realworld.title: Horticulture
realworld.description: Understanding meristematic tissues helps in plant propagation techniques like cutting and grafting, where meristematic cells facilitate new growth.

notes.title: Epithelial Tissue
points: Covers body surfaces and lines body cavities.
Types:
- Squamous: Flat cells (skin, blood vessels).
- Cuboidal: Cube-shaped (kidney tubules, glands).
- Columnar: Pillar-like (intestine lining).
- Ciliated: With hair-like projections (respiratory tract).
Functions: Protection, absorption, secretion, and sensory reception.

notes.title: Connective Tissue
points: Most abundant and widely distributed tissue.
Types:
- Loose: Areolar (between skin and muscles) and Adipose (fat storage).
- Dense: Tendons (muscle to bone) and Ligaments (bone to bone).
- Specialized: Cartilage (flexible support), Bone (rigid support), Blood (transport), and Lymph (immunity).

notes.title: Muscular Tissue
points: Responsible for movement in the body.
Types:
- Striated (Skeletal): Voluntary, attached to bones, shows striations.
- Smooth (Visceral): Involuntary, in internal organs, no striations.
- Cardiac: Found in heart, involuntary, shows faint striations, branched fibers.

notes.title: Nervous Tissue
points: Makes up the brain, spinal cord, and nerves.
Composed of neurons (nerve cells) and neuroglia (supporting cells).
Neuron structure: Cell body (contains nucleus), Dendrites (receive signals), and Axon (transmits signals).
Function: Rapid communication between different parts of the body.

formulas.title: Nerve Impulse Conduction
formulas.explanation: Sequence of electrical changes during nerve impulse transmission.

realworld.title: Medical Diagnostics
realworld.description: Tissue examination (histopathology) helps diagnose diseases like cancer by analyzing changes in tissue structure at the microscopic level.

realworld.title: Sports Medicine
realworld.description: Understanding muscle and connective tissues is crucial for treating sports injuries, where damaged tissues need proper care and rehabilitation.

notes.title: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation
points: Every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.
Formulated by Sir Isaac Newton in 1687.
Explains both the motion of celestial bodies and objects on Earth.
The force acts along the line joining the centers of the two objects.

notes.title: Mathematical Formulation
points: F ∝ m₁ × m₂ (Directly proportional to the product of masses).
F ∝ 1/r² (Inversely proportional to the square of the distance between centers).
Combining: F = G(m₁m₂)/r², where G is the universal gravitational constant (6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ Nm²/kg²).
The value of G is constant throughout the universe.

formulas.title: Universal Law of Gravitation
formulas.explanation: F is the gravitational force between two masses m₁ and m₂ separated by distance r, where G is the gravitational constant.

realworld.title: Planetary Motion
realworld.description: The motion of planets around the Sun is governed by gravity, explaining why planets follow elliptical orbits with the Sun at one focus.

topics.name: Free Fall and Acceleration due to Gravity (g)

notes.title: Free Fall
points: Motion of an object under the influence of gravitational force alone (no air resistance).
All objects, regardless of mass, fall with the same acceleration in vacuum (Galileo's experiment at Leaning Tower of Pisa).
In real conditions, air resistance affects the motion of falling objects.

notes.title: Acceleration due to Gravity (g)
points: The acceleration with which objects fall towards Earth's center (9.8 m/s² near Earth's surface).
Derived from Newton's Second Law and Law of Gravitation: g = GM/R².
Value of g decreases with altitude and depth from Earth's surface.
g is greater at poles than at the equator (due to Earth's rotation and shape).

formulas.title: Acceleration due to Gravity
formulas.explanation: g is the acceleration due to gravity, G is gravitational constant, M is Earth's mass, and R is Earth's radius.

formulas.title: Variation of g with Height
formulas.explanation: gₕ is the acceleration due to gravity at height h above Earth's surface (for h << R).

realworld.title: Skydiving
realworld.description: Skydivers reach terminal velocity when air resistance equals gravitational force, resulting in constant speed during free fall.

notes.title: Mass
points: Fundamental property of matter (scalar quantity).
SI unit: kilogram (kg).
Constant everywhere in the universe.
Measure of inertia (resistance to change in motion).

notes.title: Weight
points: Force with which a body is attracted towards the center of the Earth (vector quantity).
SI unit: newton (N).
Varies with location (altitude, depth, planet).
Formula: W = m × g, where m is mass and g is acceleration due to gravity.

notes.title: Difference Between Mass and Weight
points: Mass is a measure of matter; weight is a measure of force.
Mass is constant; weight changes with gravity.
Mass is measured using a beam balance; weight is measured using a spring balance.

formulas.title: Weight Formula
formulas.explanation: Weight (W) equals mass (m) multiplied by acceleration due to gravity (g).

formulas.title: Weight on Moon vs Earth
formulas.explanation: Weight on Moon is about 1/6th the weight on Earth due to Moon's lower gravity.

realworld.title: Space Exploration
realworld.description: Astronauts in the International Space Station experience weightlessness not because gravity is absent, but because they are in continuous free fall around Earth.

notes.title: Thrust and Pressure
points: Thrust: Force acting perpendicular to a surface (measured in newtons, N).
Pressure: Thrust per unit area (P = F/A, measured in pascal, Pa = N/m²).
Pressure increases with depth in fluids due to the weight of the overlying fluid.
Applications: Sharp knives cut better (high pressure), snowshoes prevent sinking (low pressure).

notes.title: Buoyancy and Archimedes' Principle
points: Buoyant Force: Upward force exerted by a fluid on an immersed object.
Archimedes' Principle: When a body is immersed fully or partially in a fluid, it experiences an upward force equal to the weight of the fluid displaced by it.
Floating Condition: An object floats if its weight equals the weight of the displaced fluid (buoyant force).
Density determines whether an object will float or sink in a fluid.

formulas.title: Pressure in Fluids
formulas.explanation: Pressure (P) at depth h in a fluid of density ρ, where g is acceleration due to gravity.

formulas.title: Archimedes' Principle
formulas.explanation: Buoyant force (F_b) equals the weight of the displaced fluid, where ρ is fluid density and V is volume displaced.

realworld.title: Submarine Operations
realworld.description: Submarines use ballast tanks to control buoyancy - filling tanks with water to dive and with air to surface, applying Archimedes' Principle.

realworld.title: Hydraulic Systems
realworld.description: Hydraulic lifts and brakes work on the principle that pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished in all directions, allowing small forces to lift heavy objects.

notes.title: Definition of Work in Physics
points: Work is said to be done when a force causes displacement of an object in the direction of the applied force.
Work is done only when: (1) A force acts on an object, and (2) The object is displaced in the direction of the force.
Mathematically, Work (W) = Force (F) × Displacement (s) × cosθ, where θ is the angle between force and displacement.
SI unit of work is joule (J). 1 J = 1 N × 1 m.

notes.title: Positive, Negative and Zero Work
points: Positive Work: When force and displacement are in the same direction (θ = 0°, cosθ = 1).
Negative Work: When force and displacement are in opposite directions (θ = 180°, cosθ = -1).
Zero Work: When force and displacement are perpendicular (θ = 90°, cosθ = 0) or when there is no displacement.

formulas.title: Work Done by a Force
formulas.explanation: Work is the dot product of force and displacement vectors, where θ is the angle between them.

formulas.title: Work Done Against Gravity
formulas.explanation: Work done in lifting an object of mass m to height h against gravity (g = 9.8 m/s²).

realworld.title: Climbing Stairs
realworld.description: When you climb stairs, you do work against gravity. The work done depends on your weight (mg) and the vertical height climbed (h).

notes.title: Kinetic Energy
points: Energy possessed by a moving object due to its motion.
Depends on mass (m) and velocity (v) of the object: KE = ½mv².
SI unit is joule (J).
Examples: Moving car, flowing water, wind energy.

notes.title: Potential Energy
points: Energy possessed by an object due to its position or configuration.
Gravitational Potential Energy (GPE) = mgh, where h is height above reference level.
Elastic Potential Energy = ½kx² (k = spring constant, x = displacement from mean position).
Examples: Water in a dam, stretched bow, compressed spring.

formulas.title: Kinetic Energy
formulas.explanation: Kinetic energy of an object with mass m moving with velocity v.
